channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: First Coronavirus Vaccines Bring Americans Hope in Small Doses
item.description: The vaccine campaign began on the same day that the nation surpassed 300,000 deaths, more than any other country.
item.dc:creator: Campbell Robertson, Amy Harmon and Mitch Smith
item.media:credit: Tim Gruber for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hundreds of medical workers received the United States’ first coronavirus vaccines on Monday, including Kenzie Frankl, a clinical care leader with Sanford Health in Fargo, N.D.

item.title: What’s Next for Trump Voters Who Believe the Election Was Stolen?
item.description: Some are certain the election was fraudulent. Others aren’t so sure. What becomes of their skepticism has important implications for American democracy.
item.dc:creator: Sabrina Tavernise
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of President Trump gathered for a rally in Washington on Saturday.

item.title: ‘A Shot of Hope’: What the Vaccine Is Like for Frontline Doctors and Nurses
item.description: Even as medical workers lined up for America’s first shots, many of them recalled nightmarish moments from the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Jack Healy, Lucy Tompkins and Audra D. S. Burch
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Aharon Sareli, the chief of critical care for Memorial Healthcare System, received the coronavirus vaccine at a pharmacy in Miramar, Fla., on Monday.

item.title: Early Voting Begins in Georgia for High-Stakes Senate Runoffs
item.description: Across the state, roadside signs urge residents to vote one more time. On Monday, many did, as both of the state’s G.O.P. senators face Democratic challengers.
item.dc:creator: Rick Rojas and Jannat Batra
item.media:credit: Lynsey Weatherspoon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Early voting at the Cobb County Board of Elections and Registration in Atlanta.

item.title: Moderna Vaccine Is Highly Protective and Prevents Severe Covid, Data Show
item.description: The positive review likely ensures that the F.D.A. will grant emergency authorization for a second coronavirus vaccine this week for millions of Americans.
item.dc:creator: Noah Weiland, Denise Grady and Carl Zimmer
item.media:credit: Ted S. Warren/Associated Press
item.media:description: A patient receiving a dose of the Moderna coronavirus vaccine during a trial in Washington State earlier this year.

item.title: ‘Faith in Our Institutions Held’
item.description: Biden passes an electoral milestone as the Republicans’ dam cracks: This is your morning tip sheet.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello

item.title: No Labels, Planning Centrist Push in New Congress, Taps Larry Hogan
item.description: The bipartisan organization has selected the Maryland governor, a Republican, as a leader, ramping up its campaign to influence the new Congress.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:credit: Andrew Mangum for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gov. Larry Hogan has become increasingly involved with the organization in recent months.

item.title: The Fast Path to a Vaccine
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Mark Lennihan
item.media:description: Sandra Lindsay, a nurse in Queens, is inoculated with the Pfizer-BioNTech Covid-19 vaccine.

item.title: In a Hard Year, Families Find Joy in Real Christmas Trees
item.description: Bell’s Christmas Trees in Accord, N.Y., closed early this month after its customers, worn down by the pandemic and looking for a safe family activity, bought out its entire inventory.
item.dc:creator: Christina Morales and Judith Levitt
item.media:credit: Judith Levitt for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nestled in the Hudson Valley, Bell’s Christmas Trees has been selling trees for more than two decades. “We can’t grow them fast enough,” Brian Bell said.

item.title: Black Student Expelled After Mother Complains About 'Fences'
item.description: A dispute about the reading of August Wilson’s Pulitzer Prize-winning play in an English class escalated at the mostly white Providence Day School in Charlotte, N.C.
item.dc:creator: Marie Fazio
item.media:credit: Travis Dove for The New York Times
item.media:description: Faith Fox and her son Jamel.

item.title: Inside Biden’s Struggle to Manage Factions in the Democratic Party
item.description: The competition for senior offices has strained valuable political alliances, vexing some of Joe Biden’s key supporters from the Democratic primary contest.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Burns and Jonathan Martin
item.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
item.media:description: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. introducing nominees for his cabinet in Wilmington, Del., on Friday. The selection process has brought out new tensions in the Democratic Party.

item.title: With First Dibs on Vaccines, Rich Countries Have ‘Cleared the Shelves’
item.description: The U.S., Britain, Canada and others are hedging their bets, reserving doses that far outnumber their populations, as many poorer nations struggle to secure enough.
item.dc:creator: Megan Twohey, Keith Collins and Katie Thomas
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Inside the Right-Wing Media Bubble, Where the Myth of a Trump Win Lives On
item.description: The Electoral College has affirmed Biden’s victory. That doesn’t mean that Trump-friendly news outlets have accepted it.
item.dc:creator: Jeremy W. Peters
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: The aggressive campaign by President Trump and his media boosters to insist with each new setback that the election is far from settled isn’t letting up.

item.title: Dysfunctional Prison and Court Pose Guantánamo Headaches for Biden
item.description: The new administration confronts decaying infrastructure and a military justice system moving at a glacial pace.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg, Charlie Savage and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: A prisoner in the detention center zone of the United States naval base at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba.

item.title: If Teachers Get the Vaccine Quickly, Can Students Get Back to School?
item.description: Teachers’ unions largely support plans to put educators near the front of the line, but given availability and logistics, that might not be enough to open more schools in the spring.
item.dc:creator: Eliza Shapiro and Shawn Hubler
item.media:credit: Lauren Justice for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mitch Arsenie, an environmental studies teacher at Carl Schurz High School in Chicago, teaching from home. Chicago is one of several cities where classrooms remain closed.

item.title: Dixie State University in Utah Says It’s in Need of a Name Change
item.description: The public university in St. George said about one in five recent graduates surveyed had received negative feedback from prospective out-of-state employers about the name.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor
item.category: National Assn for the Advancement of Colored People
item.media:credit: Chris Caldwell/The Spectrum, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Greater Zion Stadium at Dixie State University in St. George, Utah. The name of the university recalls the origins of some of the state’s early settlers, who sought to turn the region into a cotton-growing hub.

item.title: ‘It was important for me to do this one thing,’ a terminally ill elector said, casting his vote for Biden.
item.dc:creator: Aishvarya Kavi
item.media:credit: Ted S. Warren/Associated Press
item.media:description: Jack Arends, a member of Washington's Electoral College, waited to cast his vote at the state Capitol in Olympia, Wash. “I was glad to do my duty and rid our nation of a petty dictator,” he said.

item.title: Families at Border Present Familiar Test for Biden’s Homeland Security Pick
item.description: The Biden administration will be expected to balance demands for more lenient policies with moderates’ concerns that any show of tolerance could lead to more illegal migration.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Immigration groups have called for Alejandro N. Mayorkas, President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s pick for homeland security secretary, to roll back some Trump administration policies.

item.title: After Electoral College Votes, More Republicans Warily Accept Trump’s Loss
item.description: “At some point, you have to face the music,” said the second-ranking Senate Republican. But Senator Mitch McConnell, the majority leader, was notably silent.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Fandos
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: “It’s time for everybody to move on,” said Senator John Thune, Republican of South Dakota.

item.title: A Day That Settled an Election and Brought Hope for Defeating a Pandemic
item.description: “I honestly can’t recall two independent events of such extreme importance occurring on the same day,” said one historian. “A good day,” said another.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:credit: Nicole Craine for The New York Times
item.media:description: Georgia’s Electoral College delegates voting at the State Capitol in Atlanta on Monday. Their votes were among the 306 cast for President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr., affirming his election victory.

item.title: Scope of Russian Hack Becomes Clear: Multiple U.S. Agencies Were Hit
item.description: The Pentagon, intelligence agencies, nuclear labs and Fortune 500 companies use software that was found to have been compromised by Russian hackers. The sweep of stolen data is still being assessed.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger, Nicole Perlroth and Eric Schmitt
item.media:credit: Brendan Mcdermid/Reuters
item.media:description: About 18,000 private and government users downloaded a tainted software update that gave Russian hackers a foothold into victims’ systems, according to SolarWinds, the company whose software was compromised.

item.title: Moderates Pare Back Stimulus Plan in Hopes of Breaking Stalemate
item.description: The group separated out the two most contentious issues — aid for state and local governments and liability protection for businesses — aiming for a consensus that could be agreed upon before week’s end.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Joe Manchin III, Democrat of West Virginia, on Monday with a bipartisan group of lawmakers at the Capitol.

item.title: Electoral College Vote Officially Affirms Biden’s Victory
item.description: The vote made official Joe Biden’s victory, despite President Trump’s attempt to subvert the nation’s democratic process, and it put pressure on Republicans to acknowledge the outcome.
item.dc:creator: Nick Corasaniti and Jim Rutenberg
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: President-elect Joe Biden spoke just hours after the Electoral College formally cast its votes.

item.title: With Selfies, Emojis and Little Disruption, the Electoral College Makes It Official
item.description: Some electors met in person to carry out their duties, and statehouses were on high alert for protests. Others stayed remote, and completed yet another 2020 task on Zoom.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Morry Gash
item.media:description: Gov. Tony Evers of Wisconsin greeting a member of the state’s Electoral College delegation after it cast its votes on Monday at the State Capitol in Madison.

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: Vaccinations Begin in the U.S.
item.description: A moment of hope, as the country passes another tragic milestone.
item.dc:creator: Adam Pasick and Amelia Nierenberg

item.title: No, Republican attempts to organize ‘alternate’ electors won’t affect the official Electoral College tally.
item.dc:creator: Aishvarya Kavi
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Stephen Miller, an adviser to President Trump, said that Republicans in several states would enter “alternate” electoral college votes. But they do not have the legal authority to do so.

item.title: 4 Takeaways From Biden’s Electoral College Victory
item.description: Joe Biden was confirmed as the winner of the election, but President Trump’s war on the results is likely to have lasting effects for the country.
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher and Adam Nagourney
item.media:credit: Nicole Craine for The New York Times
item.media:description: Democratic electors in Georgia gathered on Monday at the State Capitol in Atlanta to cast their Electoral College votes.

item.title: Representative Paul Mitchell leaves Republican Party over its refusal to accept Trump’s loss.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Fandos
item.media:credit: Susan Walsh/Associated Press
item.media:description: In a letter announcing his decision, Representative Paul Mitchell warned that by continuing to align themselves with President Trump, top Republicans would do “long-term harm to our democracy.”

item.title: William Barr Is Out as Attorney General
item.description: Mr. Barr was one of the most powerful members of President Trump’s cabinet and faced widespread criticism over his willingness to advance Mr. Trump’s political agenda.
item.dc:creator: Katie Benner
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: Attorney General William P. Barr quickly became a trusted adviser to President Trump.

item.title: California’s electors are meeting now. Their votes are expected to push Biden over the top.
item.dc:creator: Sydney Ember
item.media:credit: Jonathan Drake/Reuters
item.media:description: North Carolina Electoral College representatives signing the Certificates of Vote in the State Capitol building in Raleigh, N.C., in 2016.

item.title: Fruit Flies Are Essential to Science. So Are the Workers Who Keep Them Alive.
item.description: Sustaining the world’s biggest Drosophila collection during the pandemic has been a challenge, but the people in Indiana who supply the insects to labs around the world stay dedicated to the task.
item.dc:creator: Cara Giaimo
item.media:credit: Kaiti Sullivan for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Flipped” vials that had contained fruit flies in the Bloomington Drosophila Stock Center at Indiana University.

item.title: The Next Covid Vaccine Challenge: Reassuring Older Americans
item.description: The two leading coronavirus vaccines seemed to work well in elderly trial volunteers. “I just can’t understand why people are afraid,” one 95-year-old said.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:credit: Cassidy Araiza for The New York Times
item.media:description: Frank Bruno in his studio in Rio Rico, Ariz., on Sunday. Mr. Bruno, 95, participated in the trial of the Moderna vaccine.

item.title: U.S. Imposes Sanctions on Turkey Over 2017 Purchase of Russian Missile Defenses
item.description: Trump had resisted the economic penalties against Turkey in favor of his personal relationship with President
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:credit: Dimitar Dilkoff/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A rocket was launched from an S-400 missile system at the Ashuluk military base in Russia. Turkey’s purchase of the system prompted the sanctions.

item.title: Biden calls Trump’s attacks on voting ‘unconscionable.’
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: President-elect Joe Biden spoke just hours after the Electoral College formally cast its votes.

item.title: The U.S. Passes 300,000 Coronavirus Deaths
item.dc:creator: Amy Harmon
item.media:credit: Callaghan O'Hare/Reuters
item.media:description: One of the more than 300,000 coronavirus deaths in the U.S., a patient who died at United Memorial Medical Center in Houston, was covered before being removed from the ICU.

item.title: Michigan Republican leaders affirm state’s electoral votes and reprimand lawmaker who suggested there might be violence.
item.dc:creator: Sydney Ember, Kathleen Gray and Glenn Thrush
item.media:credit: Brittany Greeson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters outside the State Capitol in Lansing, Mich., on Monday as the Electoral College prepared to cast its votes.

item.title: Schools Will Close in Germany as Cases Surge
item.description: Even in a country once seen as a success story, the second wave is taking a toll on education
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg and Adam Pasick

item.title: In Iowa, an emergency room nurse is first in line for vaccination.
item.dc:creator: John Peragine
item.media:credit: Kathryn Gamble for The New York Times
item.media:description: David Conway, 39, an emergency-room nurse, was the first staff member to receive the vaccine at the University of Iowa Hospital in Iowa City on Monday.

item.title: Wisconsin’s Supreme Court denies a last-ditch Trump effort to toss 200,000 votes from Milwaukee and Madison.
item.dc:creator: Reid J. Epstein
item.media:credit: Tannen Maury/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Election observers, right, watching election officials during the recount of ballots in Milwaukee last month.

item.title: Watch live: Electors to vote in Pennsylvania.
item.media:credit: Mark Makela for The New York Times

item.title: Hearing Aids Could Use Some Help
item.description: The vital medical devices could be inexpensive and available over the counter. But efforts have stalled under the F.D.A.
item.dc:creator: Paula Span
item.media:credit: Isabel Seliger

item.title: Early voting begins in the Georgia runoffs, which will determine control of the Senate.
item.dc:creator: Rick Rojas
item.media:credit: Lynsey Weatherspoon for The New York Times
item.media:description: People waiting in line to vote in Atlanta on Monday.

item.title: Mary Nichols Appears to Be Out of Running to Lead E.P.A.
item.description: The president-elect’s transition team is scrambling to find a new candidate for the E.P.A. after advocates objected to Mary D. Nichols.
item.dc:creator: Coral Davenport
item.media:credit: Rich Pedroncelli/Associated Press
item.media:description: Mary D. Nichols, head of the California Air Resources Board, with Gov. Gavin Newsom last year.

item.title: U.S. Imposes Sanctions on 2 Iranian Officials in Robert Levinson Case
item.description: The Treasury imposed sanctions on two Interior Ministry officials, who it said were “involved in the abduction, detention and probable death” of Mr. Levinson, a former F.B.I. agent.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:credit: Christine Levinson, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Robert Levinson, a former F.B.I. agent, disappeared under mysterious circumstances off Iran’s Kish Island in March 2007.
